quiz.title: Unit 7: Labor Markets (Quiz 26)
quiz.subtitle: 7.2 The Labor Demand Curve: Graphical Labor Demand (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Labor Demand Curve, MRP Curve, Shifts vs. Movements, Graphical Analysis

questions.question: The labor demand curve for an individual firm is graphically represented by:
options: The average product of labor curve
questions.explanation: For a profit-maximizing firm, the labor demand curve is the MRP curve because the firm hires workers up to the point where $W = MRP$.

questions.question: On a graph with wage on the vertical axis and quantity of labor on the horizontal axis, the labor demand curve slopes:
questions.explanation: The labor demand curve slopes downward because as wages decrease, firms are willing to hire more workers (higher quantity demanded at lower prices).

questions.question: A movement along the labor demand curve occurs when:
questions.explanation: Changes in the wage rate cause movement along the demand curve, while other factors (technology, output price) shift the entire curve.

questions.question: If the market wage increases from $W_1$ to $W_2$, on the labor demand graph this causes:
options: A rightward shift of the demand curve
A leftward shift of the demand curve
Movement upward along the demand curve
Movement downward along the demand curve
questions.explanation: A wage increase causes upward movement along the demand curve, resulting in a lower quantity of labor demanded.

questions.question: The labor demand curve for a perfectly competitive firm in the product market is:
options: The same as the VMP (value of marginal product) curve
The same as the MRP curve but below VMP
Perfectly elastic at the market wage
questions.explanation: For perfect competitors, $P = MR$, so $MRP = MP \times P = VMP$, making the labor demand curve the same as the VMP curve.

questions.question: For a monopoly in the product market, the labor demand curve lies:
options: On top of the VMP curve
To the right of the VMP curve
questions.explanation: Since monopolists have $MR < P$, their $MRP = MP \times MR$ is less than $VMP = MP \times P$, so labor demand is below VMP.

questions.question: An increase in worker productivity would cause the labor demand curve to:
questions.explanation: Higher productivity increases MRP at each employment level, shifting the labor demand curve rightward.

questions.question: On a labor demand graph, the area under the MRP curve up to the quantity hired represents:
questions.explanation: The area under the MRP curve represents total revenue attributable to labor, since MRP is the additional revenue from each worker.

questions.question: If the price of a firm's output decreases, the labor demand curve will:
questions.explanation: Lower output price reduces MRP at each employment level, decreasing labor demand and shifting the curve leftward.

questions.question: The market labor demand curve is derived by:
options: Summing individual firms' demand curves horizontally
Taking the highest MRP among firms
questions.explanation: At each wage rate, sum the quantities of labor demanded by all firms to get the market labor demand curve.

questions.question: When graphing labor demand, the vertical distance between the MRP curve and the wage line at the profit-maximizing quantity represents:
options: The rent earned by inframarginal workers
questions.explanation: Inframarginal workers (those hired before the last worker) have MRP > wage, creating economic rent - the surplus the firm earns from these workers.

questions.question: A technological improvement that is labor-saving would cause the labor demand curve to:
options: Shift rightward due to output effect but leftward due to substitution effect
questions.explanation: Labor-saving technology has conflicting effects: substitution effect reduces labor demand, but output effect (lower costs, more output) may increase it. The net effect is ambiguous.

questions.question: On a labor demand graph, the firm's total wage bill is represented by:
options: The area under the MRP curve
The rectangle: wage × quantity of labor
The triangle above the wage line
The vertical intercept of the demand curve
questions.explanation: Total wage cost = wage rate × quantity of labor hired, which is the area of the rectangle from the origin to the equilibrium point.

questions.question: If labor and capital are complements in production, an increase in the price of capital will cause the labor demand curve to:
questions.explanation: For complements, higher price of one input reduces demand for both inputs, shifting labor demand leftward.

questions.question: The elasticity of labor demand is reflected in the graph by:
options: The vertical position of the curve
The horizontal position of the curve
questions.explanation: Flatter demand curves are more elastic (quantity responds greatly to wage changes), while steeper curves are more inelastic.

questions.question: In the short run with fixed capital, the labor demand curve is:
options: More elastic than in the long run
Less elastic than in the long run
questions.explanation: Short-run labor demand is less elastic because firms cannot adjust capital, making substitution more difficult.

questions.question: On a labor market graph, consumer surplus from hiring labor is:
options: The area above the wage line and below the demand curve
The area below the wage line and above the demand curve
The total area under the demand curve
questions.explanation: The area above the wage and below the demand curve represents the surplus firms get from workers whose MRP exceeds their wage.

questions.question: If a minimum wage is set above the equilibrium wage, on the labor demand graph this creates:
questions.explanation: At the higher wage, quantity demanded decreases while quantity supplied increases, creating unemployment (surplus of labor).

questions.question: The backward-bending labor supply curve, when combined with a typical labor demand curve, can result in:
questions.explanation: The backward-bending supply curve can intersect the demand curve at multiple points, creating potential for multiple equilibria.

questions.question: Graphically, the difference between a firm's MRP and VMP curves represents:
options: The monopoly power in the product market
The monopsony power in the labor market
questions.explanation: The gap between VMP and MRP measures the firm's market power in the product market, since $VMP - MRP = MP \times (P - MR)$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand the graphical representation of labor demand and can interpret various labor market scenarios.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but should review the relationship between MRP and labor demand, and factors causing shifts vs. movements.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: how the labor demand curve relates to MRP, reading labor market graphs, and distinguishing shifts from movements.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that the labor demand curve is the MRP curve, and it slopes downward due to diminishing marginal product.
